brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to compare the impact of high- and low-intensity resistance
      exercise on force-velocity characteristics, muscle mass and inflammatory processes in older
      adults. As all training protocols are designed to end with maximal effort, effects are
      expected to be similar between groups.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Effects of Low- and High-intensity Resistance Exercise on Force-velocity Characteristics in Older Adults
clinical_study.condition: Effects of Strength Training in Older Adults

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  age 60 to 80 years

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Knee or hip prothesis

          -  Systematic training

          -  Cardiovascular disease

          -  Acute lower back pain

          -  Dementia

facility.name: Faculty of Kinesiology and Rehabilitation Sciences

other_outcome.description: Strength is measured as the maximum weight on the training equipment that can be lifted only one time (= one repetition maximum).
other_outcome.measure: Change in maximal strength (one repetition maximum)

other_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, every week for 12 weeks, 6 months

other_outcome.measure: Change in inflammatory markers in blood

primary_outcome.measure: Change in force-velocity characteristics of knee extensors

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject)
